data.title: Chicago Public Schools
data.meta_description: Meet the Chicago Public Schools Executive Leadership team, who are focused on providing students in every neighborhood of the city with equitable access to high-quality education and facilities.
data.text:
Prior to this role, she served as Chief Schools Officer and was responsible for managing Chicago's 17 school networks and the Independent Schools Principals (ISP) Network by ensuring principal quality and strong school performance across the District. She began her CPS career as a special education teacher at Frederic Chopin Elementary School and was also selected to open the K–8 Disney II Magnet School in 2008 and oversee its 9-12 grade expansion in 2012. Under her leadership, Disney II consistently performed in the top 10 percent of all Illinois public elementary schools and in 2012 achieved the School of Excellence designation from the Illinois State Board of Education.

Bogdana holds a bachelor of science in special education from South-West University in Bulgaria, a master's degree in educational administration from Governors State University, and is currently completing her doctorate in educational leadership from Western Illinois University.

Dr. Sofia Adawy Akintunde is a Family Medicine physician who, over the last two decades, has dedicated her life and career to education, social justice, and healing.

Prior to working at CPS, she served as Senior Health Center Director at the Inner-City Muslim Action Network (IMAN), a Federally Qualified Health Center on Chicago’s South Side, leading the organization’s transition from a free clinic to an FQHC, as well as serving as the sole physician on staff during the COVID-19 pandemic, and guiding the pivots in policies, public health response, and delivery of clinical care. Dr. Sofia’s previous work also includes clinical and academic roles at the University of Illinois at Chicago College of Medicine, University of Illinois Hospital and Health Sciences System, and Mile Square Health Center. Prior to her career in medicine, she taught high school Biology, Health, and American Literature. She is a first-generation Egyptian American who grew up in the Greater Chicagoland Area.

Dr. Sofia holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology from the University of Chicago and earned her Doctorate of Medicine degree from the University of Illinois at Chicago College of Medicine. She completed her residency in Family Medicine at University of Illinois Hospital and Health Sciences System as well as the Scholars for Teaching Excellence Faculty Fellowship and the Midwest Fellowship for Primary Care Champions. She is a Fellow of the American Academy of Family Physicians and is nearing completion of a certification in Functional Medicine.

Dr. Sofia speaks Arabic and Spanish in addition to English. She is a wife and a mother to two toddlers and a puppy. Her interests include food, fashion, music, niche areas of history, collecting works from living artists, and being near the ocean.

He also spent 13 years in public accounting including 4 years as an auditor with Ernst & Young, LLP in Chicago. Patrick graduated Magna Cum Laude with a degree in Bachelor of Science in Commerce major in Accounting from Xavier University in Cagayan de Oro, Philippines. He is a CPA both in Illinois, USA and in the Philippines. He ranked 20th place in the 1992 National Philippine CPA Board Examination.

Patrick attended a public elementary school in the Philippines. Patrick has lived in Chicago, IL since migrating from the Philippines in 2000.

As a school administrator, she served at CPS elementary and high schools, with a particular focus on programmatic innovation, biliteracy, and diverse learner support in inclusive settings. Under her leadership, these schools showed strong and consistent academic growth due to her focus on meaningful student engagement, social-emotional supports, professional learning, and distributive leadership.

Most recently as Chief of Network 4, Asaf was responsible for 35 elementary schools on the city’s North Side. As a Network Chief, she collaborated with school leaders to ensure that educators and students felt safe and supported while having the resources necessary to discover their academic genius. Previously, Asaf served as the Deputy Chief for Network 7, where she assisted school leaders serving Pilsen, Little Village, and other West Side neighborhoods.

Asaf holds a doctorate in educational leadership and a Master’s degree in reading and special education from DePaul University. Her Bachelor’s degree is from Northeastern Illinois University in bilingual/multicultural education with a minor in Spanish literature.

In 2010, Dr. Carmona was named principal of Healy Elementary School, and by 2016, this school had been ranked among the Top 10 CPS elementary schools by Chicago Magazine and a Distinguished School by the National Title IX School Association.

Dr. Carmona’s most recent role with CPS was as the Chief of Network 10, where he provided support and guidance to students, teachers, and school leaders. He holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Economics from the University of Cartagena in Columbia, as well as two Master’s Degrees - one in Curriculum and Instruction from the University of Illinois at Chicago and one in Educational Leadership from American College of Education. He earned his Doctorate in School Administration from Western Illinois University, and met his wife, also a CPS educator, when they were both teaching in Chicago’s Back of the Yards community.

Prior to joining CPS, Mr. Fleming was Vice President of Global Business Transformation at McCormick & Co., Senior Director of IT Project & Portfolio Management at Aon Service Corporation, Senior Director of IT Enterprise Business Solutions at Molson Coors, Senior Director of IT Client Relationship Management at Astellas Pharma, Program Integration & Management lead at Deloitte Consulting, Global IT Manager at Merck & Co., Director of Client Services Systems at The New York Times Company, Business Systems Manager at Kraft Heinz Foods Company, and held various leadership positions at the Chicago Tribune Company.

Norm is a proud graduate of Illinois Public Schools. He holds a Master of Business Administration from Keller Graduate School of Management of DeVry University and a Bachelor of Science in Management from Southern Illinois University at Carbondale. He is a certified Project Management Professional (PMP), Lean Six Sigma Green Belt (LSSB), and IT Infrastructure Library (ITIL) practitioner.

Whether it was managing the rollout of modern schools, improving access and safety to a public library, or implementing facility assessments for the first time in almost a decade, Ivan has worked within the government to make positive impacts on public facilities for the residents of Chicago. Over the years, Ivan has cultivated excellent working relationships with the various trades unions that are instrumental in delivering this work.

Prior to joining the District, Ivan served as the Deputy Commissioner for Facility Operations for the City of Chicago and was responsible for all the day-to-day operations in over 500 city facilities including managing over 1,200 city and contracted employees. He developed many new initiatives including a major energy retrofit project saving the city over $1 million a month in utility savings.

Hernandez has extensive experience in the world of procurement, with more than 25 years of service in various roles at CPS. She began her career at CPS with the Department of Investigations and Office of the Inspector General before moving to the Department of Procurement; with experience at all levels of the procurement process, Hernandez has worked her way up from senior buyer to her current role.

Hernandez is a graduate of the University of Illinois - Chicago and throughout her career has obtained several certifications, including Certified Public Procurement Buyer (CPPB). She is also a member of numerous procurement organizations, including the Institute for Public Procurement (NIGP) and the Illinois Association of Public Procurement Officials (IAPPO).

Prior to this role, Megan served as the Chief of Schools for Network 16, where she oversaw the growth and day-to-day operations of 17 high schools on Chicago’s South and Southwest Sides. In this position, she expanded academic opportunities for diverse student populations and led the development and opening of three high schools. She also has experience as a teacher and high school administrator and is a proud parent of two CPS graduates. She lives in the South Shore community where she continues to connect with former students, volunteer, and serve as a block club member.

Megan holds an undergraduate degree from the University of Michigan, a master’s degree in curriculum and instruction from the University of New Orleans, a master’s degree in educational leadership from National Louis University, and is completing her doctorate in education policy, organization and leadership at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.

Before this role, he served as the principal of Southside Occupational Academy, a transition center for CPS students with disabilities, for more than a decade. He led the creation of numerous vocational learning labs, a school-wide functional curriculum, a differentiated student assessment system, and community-based classrooms across Chicago. He first joined CPS in 2000 as a speech-language pathologist.

He earned his bachelor’s degree in psychology and speech and hearing sciences from Indiana University, a master’s degree in communication disorders from the University of North Dakota, and a master’s degree in educational administration from Governors State University. He was a 2016 Cahn Fellow through Columbia University and the proud recipient of the 2019 Golden Apple Stanley C. Golder Leadership Award.

Throughout her 20 years within CPS, Leslie has served as a preschool teacher, instructional coach, professional learning manager, and director of Head Start and Preschool Programs. In her role as deputy chief officer, she led the universal Pre-K expansion strategy and centralized preschool application process for the district. Through a cross-departmental and cross-agency approach, Leslie has launched the OECE vision and the Preschool to 2nd Grade strategy, including the creation of the P-2 Program Management Office.

Leslie is also the parent of a CPS student who joyfully started her education in an early childhood preschool classroom. She earned her bachelor of arts in early childhood education at Delaware State University and her master’s of arts in administration and supervision at National Louis University.

She most recently served as the Chief of Schools for Network 6, overseeing 23 elementary schools on Chicago’s Near South, Near West, and Near North Sides. In this role, she focused on providing professional coaching for school leaders and staff to support student learning and growth. She also served as the principal of Mitchell Elementary School for eight years. Before joining CPS in 2009, she worked as a teacher in Newark, NJ and Washington, D.C.

She holds a master of business administration from Yale University, a master of education leadership from Harvard University, and a bachelor’s degree in psychology from Amherst College.

This role is a natural transition from her previous position as Deputy Chief of Elementary Schools, where she focused on supporting network chiefs and principals to assist schools in attaining their achievement goals. A proud CPS graduate and parent, she has also served as a teacher, assistant principal, principal, deputy chief, and the Chief of Network 9 in her 30-year career with the District. As a principal, her school consistently showed strong academic growth through her focus on community partnerships and social-emotional learning.

Felicia completed her undergraduate studies at Northern Illinois University and holds a master's degree in educational administration from Chicago State University. Additionally, she received her superintendent license and training at the University of Illinois Chicago.
